title: Z-Probe extruder mount for Solidoodle, for auto bed leveling

description.text: This is a derivative of Lawsy's Mk4 extruder (only the lower part) with a bracket that can accommodate a micro servo motor (11mm height, like this: http://www.adafruit.com/products/169). It also includes an arm where the Z-stop switch can be fitted.

Print the extruder part with high infill (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:47561 for instructions and other components of the extruder). Fit the servo motor in the bracket, securing it with some glue or tape. Print the arm at low infill, and screw the Z-stop switch on the larger end.
Attach the arm to the pivot of the servo using the screw provided with the motor to secure it in place (see picture) For information on how to wire the servo and enable the auto bed leveling, see the Soliforum (http://www.soliforum.com/topic/4714/automatic-bed-leveling-and-z-offset-howto-level-23/).

title: Print it Forward: Learn to build a 3D printer for your classroom!

description.text:
Our Maker Club designed this 3D printer kit.

Build Instructions: https://sites.google.com/a/mrwatt.ca/print-it-forward/

Maker Club CTV Interview: https://youtu.be/y6Btoy-aop0

Students learn about technology by making their own 3D printer then are able to build and donate printer kits to other schools - printing it forward. The concept isn't new, we've tried to create a machine that is simple to build yet reliable. With hands on connections to Math, Science and Technology its a fantastic way to integrate practical learning into the classroom and build connections with other schools and districts.

We've had our hands full with this project for over a year helping out numerous schools. Originally we posted it on Youmagine for about a year ago: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/printrbot-labs-kit

This started as a riff on the original Printrbot and become something different. Posted here is the most recent iteration that uses hardware spacing from the Printrbot Play. We've recently updated the clearances to help parts print well on a variety of 3D printers.

We've had fun with this project, I hope you do too!

Demo Print: https://youtu.be/SrXIRCj0axs

Printrbot Learn Site: http://learn.printrbot.com/2016/05/19/print-it-forward/

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

35%

Notes:

This printer can be configured by extending its bed to print all of its own printed parts. While this works we use a large printrbot with heated bed to mass produce the components we needed for several schools. It can be printed entirely in PLA but we like to do the extruder and X axis parts in ABS.

This design uses many of the same spacing and remixes parts from the Printrbot Play http://printrbot.com/product-category/3d-printers/play-4x4x5/ so all of the upgrades are compatible.

Source:

https://www.youmagine.com/designs/printrbot-play-components

https://www.youmagine.com/designs/printrbot-play-model

Remixes of this project:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1741663

3D printers are expensive and their mechanics can be difficult to understand. This educational project enables students to inexpensively build their own 3D printer and learn about the technology along the way. http://learn.printrbot.com/2016/05/19/print-it-forward/

Introduction This is a hands on activity that is divided into 4 parts: Building, Coding, Calibrating and Designing. All materials required are listed in the Bill of Materials: https://sites.google.com/a/mrwatt.ca/print-it-forward/bill-of-materials Audience We've successfully built these printers with middle school and high school students. We donate the printers to local schools that need the tech. Its a great way for teachers and students to connect with other schools in their community. Requirements This project is best when it is student lead, however you need a teacher who knows enough about the technology to help when students are totally stuck. For some this will mean building on yourself before taking on this challenge with a class, for others it will mean reading a few steps ahead to understand what is needed. Building a printer for the first time is hard - I let the kids build, make mistakes and learn - this takes longer but it is also makes it a much richer task. We build our printers after school and it takes about 6-8 one hour meet ups to get one printing - it would be faster if we weren't having so much fun. The project can be appended or expanded depending on your learning goals. Build Instructions This is an experiential lesson. Build instructions can be found here: https://sites.google.com/a/mrwatt.ca/print-it-forward/build-instructions They are updated pretty regularly. Feel free to leave a message me if you need anything.

This printer can be built for under $300. Printrbot.com carries a kit that we used for many of these builds but they can also be sourced on your own easily online. https://sites.google.com/a/mrwatt.ca/print-it-forward/bill-of-materials

If you are a Master/Mistress of... ...Middleages wars you will most probably have no pockets in your armor. No problem! Now you can use this accessory to keep your iPhone handy in the battle field. Pictures: http://www.flickr.com/photos/aubenc/sets/72157629248933804/ No source files??? Oups, sorry, I've done this is a hurry since I uploaded my previous thing and the code is a mess of harcoded bits here and there.

The zip file contains everything (and nothing more) that's available to download. This being said: Print, assemble, smash! Print one of each STL but for:
  • Spikes and their nuts, you need 12 of each.
  • Chain Bolt and their nuts, you need 2 of each.
    • If you need/would like other instructions, please check "iFlail.pdf" for a picture by picture assembly guide. I don't have an iPhone so I took a look to the different iPhone models in thingiverse for the 3 major dimensions. Everything has been designed with tolerances that should ensure a good fit. If you have problems with the threads (and they look good shaped) you can ream a little beat the nuts (light ream with a sharp knife) and decrease the outer diameter of the bolts with a file. Ensure that you don't smash too much the 1st layer and everything should be ok for a decently fine tuned printer. The tap in the two handle parts is located at the bottom (build point of view) so you can stop the print if the threads don't look good. The tallest part is something like 120mm, the largests are +/- 85mm for the rings and +/- 70mm x 90mm for the chain. Do post a comment if you need some help!

title: Custom tripod bracket adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This generator creates adapters for items with simple pivot joints which then can be mounted in tripods and other mounts utilizing most wedge/"shoe" quick release/fastener systems. Works well for many type of camera/video lights and tripods with quick release plates.

By specifying the correct parameters the original nuts/bolts can be reused in the printed adapter.

Printer:

FlashForge Finder

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

any

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Object prints fine without need for rafts or supports (make sure "print"orientation is selected in Customizer before saving/creating). When printing in PLA, 30% infill generally seems to provide enough strength/stiffness.

The example file is for an adapter to attach a Neewer CN-160 LED video light to a Davis & Sanford Traveler tripod and was created using the Customizer.

It was created using the following options:

display-printing tab:
$fn = 36
orientation = 1 (view)

bracket-pivot tab:
Tip_Radius = 7.5
Tip_Width = 20.24
Bracket_Length = 25.4
Bracket_Width = 14
Slot_Length = 21.8
Slot_Width = 5.7

pivot-bolt tab:
Nut_Size = 7.9
Nut_Depth = 3.5
Bolt_Diameter = 4.8
Bolt_Neck_Diameter = 11
Bolt_Neck_Depth = -3

base tab:
Base_X = 38.2
Base_Y = 0
Corner_Rounding = 30
Base_Z = 6.3
Wedge_Angle = 35
Wedge_Start = 1

Changing just the "Base_X" value from 38.2 to 28.3 will create an adapter to connect the lamp to a Targus TG-5060TR tripod, a small and somewhat flimsy tripod which is not great for typical cameras but OK with lightweight lamps.

description.text:
A 3D viewer for seeing Free 3D. Also called side by side, cross eye or (x) as well.(The steps to use are at the bottom)

Free 3D is similar to Magic Eye as there are learning hurdles that many people find difficult. Now with my new array of Ez 2C 3D viewers at http://www.headscapes.com we can show nearly 95% to see instantly as well as learn to see on their own, without a viewer, once they learn the method.

Just developed recently is the Mini Trainer that can help you learn to see this amazing world of 3D Videos and Pictures already on the Internet. It works with the same concept as the first Training Viewer now available on Ebay, except that viewer has lenses added into the design so people can see instantly without having to learn the method. http://www.ebay.com/itm/332052296824?

I want to Help everyone to See and Also Make Free 3D Videos. To start making 3D videos all you need is 2 GoPros. We have a tutorial video on Vimeo that will show you how. https://vimeo.com/194164895

And also developed are camera mount systems that align the cameras to help you make better videos and pictures. http://www.ebay.com/itm/-/332052460670?

How to use after assembly :
Step 1 - Close Left eye. Align right eye with Left Picture.
Step 2 - Close Right eye and align with Left Picture.
Step 3 - Open both eyes and cross eyes til both picture merge.
Alternate Step 3 - Bring a finger up into view til you see with both eyes. Focus on finger and pictures will merge into 3D behind the finger.

Enjoy,
Leo

title: Executor Greebled (and sliced 6x)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This remix started when I stumbled across this impressive model but realized that to achieve the scale it deserved I'd need to slice it up into sections. I also wanted to pack in a bit more detail and interest into the model so I opted for using the Greebles plugin for 3ds max (source: http://max.klanky.com/plugins.htm). The topology for the original model leaved a lot to be desired so I decided to clean up a lot of the top side faces before applying the Greebles modifier. I've also opted for using support rods throughout most of the major sections of the ship to give it that extra rigidity and strength come glue time (or if you want to feel like a ship builder give friction welding a go!) After Greebling (If it's not a term I'll coin it) the ship I exported it to netfabb for slicing and repair work. Please note that the files aren't to scale or correct orientation. The best orientation is having the largest flat side on the print bed which should use the least support required come slicing (as per screenshots). I had to scale each piece to 25% to fit my standard FlashForge Pro print bed. You will need to use support in whatever slicer you use and I strongly recommend Simplify 3d (known for fast slicing). Even on my G3258 OC to 4.5ghz slicing took between 5-10 mins on some of the more complex sections :/ You have been warned!

Original model poly count is around 200k, greebles ups this to nearly 8 million. I'm not sure what the finally tally is after netfabb cleanup.

I'm currently printing Part03 and it's going for over 20 hours so far and looks to be just over half done! So I might have to fine tune the speed a bit more.

I'm sure someone out there has an army of bots to print each part out simultaneously. Be very interested to see their results. Open to hear feedback, but please be kind as it's my first remix attempt of any kind.

  • Update 16/12/16
    Have now finished printing and assembly (see make) and now looking to fixing gaps in print due to warping before paint.
    My measurements of the completed ship come in at 68x22cm

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

100-200 microns

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Recommend going for the optimal balance of speed vs. precision here.
10% infill honeycomb
2-3 shells
60/90mms as a ballpark

Scale - 25% if you want it to fit your ffpro stock bed and use .9mm dowels.

Join with good glue, I'll be trying some Plumbers PVC Cement (Clear)
For extra support I'm going to be using .9mm wooden dowels from my local hardware store @ $1.50 a metre.

These will only be .9mm for users using 25% scale like I have maxed out for my FFpro bed. If you can scale this model higher for your monster bed then go for it, but your print times will also go through the roof! And the Dowel holes will scale accordingly (obviously).

remixed_from.author: pleppik
remixed_from.title: Super-Simple Up Feed Mechanism with Adjustable Spring

title: Super-Simple Up Feed Mechanism with Adjustable Spring V2

description.text: A remix of pleppik's Super-Simple Up Feed Mechanism with Adjustable Spring to include a spot for the filament guide tube to fit (required on my Up Plus for some reason).

Printer Brand:

Up!

Printer:

Up Plus

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Fine

Infill:

Solid

Instructions

You will need two additional parts for this mechanism:

1) A pen clip from a Pilot Precise V7 Rolling Ball pen (or the equivalent). I got a package of these pens from Staples for just a few bucks. Other pen clips may also work, provided that the clip is made with a bent piece of steel about 0.5mm thick and 5-6mm wide.

2) An M3 screw, at least 12mm long, to provide the spring adjustment mechanism.

The assembly photos should be (mostly) self-explanatory. Here are the step-by-step assembly instructions:

1) Print both STL files. I recommend the highest fill settings for strength.

2) Remove the clip from the pen. You can use the pen for other purposes--they're nice pens.

3) Using pliers, make two bends in the pen clip as illustrated in the photo. The first bend should be away from the "bump" at the end of the clip, and about 7mm from the top of the bump. The second bend should be about 17mm from the first. You can be a millimeter or two inaccurate and it will still work.

4) Leave about 10mm of the end of the clip, and cut off the excess.

5) Set the clip at a diagonal between the three retainer pegs on the feed mechanism as shown in Assembly Step 1. Do not try to bend the clip or force it! This could easily knock one of the pegs off.

6) Rotate the clip so it is horizontal between the three retainer pegs as shown in Assembly Step 2. At this point it should be held securely to the feed mechanism, but slide back and forth easily.

7) Screw the M3 bolt as shown in Assembly Step 3. This will provide tension when filament is loaded, and keep the clip from sliding out.

8) Attach the Connector Holder as shown in Assembly Step 4.

9) Attach the connector PCB from the printer to the Connector Holder, using the original screws from the connector PCB, as shown in Assembly Step 5.

10) Attach the entire assembly to the filament feed stepper as shown in Assembly Step 6, again using the original screws from the Up.

Re-mount the feed mechanism to the printer, and you're ready to go. You can tighten the adjustment screw to compensate for variations in filament diameter--but I've found it works just fine left at a fairly tight setting all the time. The polished steel of the pen clip provides almost no friction against ABS.

Note that this design does not provide a place to mount the extruder cover. I haven't used the cover almost since Day 1, and I find it mostly just gets in the way.

WARNING:

Children can fall into bucket and drown.
Keep children away from buckets with even a small amount of liquid.

Scale in Customizer by changing "ounces" value.

I needed to design some attachments for 5-gallon buckets so I figured I'd go one step further than to duplicate the general shape and tried to make it as accurate as possible. This is a 1:1 scale model. If you wish to make 3D-printable miniature buckets you'll want to tweak the parameters to prevent from losing any detail.

Some parts are 1/16th of an inch thick so directly scaling the model down to H0 (1:87) for example would require a printer capable of printing at 18.25 microns ... a printer with a 0.4mm nozzle could theoretically print this bucket scaled down 25.2% without losing the details.

If you need to subtract the bucket's external surface in OpenSCAD you can use bucket_space() which will omit the rings and handle attachment parts that bucket() includes which should save you some processing time.

title: MakerGear M2 18mm Inductive Prob Bracket for Auto Level

description.text:
This is a simple mount for a 18mm OD Inductive Bed probe such as: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008FZC8F2
I was able to get this probe to work with the Stock Borosilicate Glass build plate and the aluminum plate below on the MakerGear M2. - Your results may vary, and I take no responsibility for damage to printers or wasted money if you cannot get it to work on your printer.

Typical Inductive probes only have a 4mm sense distance (when used with steel) and will not work with the Stock MakerGear M2 Glass. This Larger probe (18mm OD) has a 8mm Sense distance (With steel) and works for me for Auto bed leveling on the M2

This modification will require a firmware modification, to enable the inductive probe for use as a Z endstop, and to enable the Auto Bed leveling routine.
This modification will aslo require the use of two (or more) resistors to create a 5V output (using a Voltage Divider) from the sensor for input into the Control board. The resistor values will vary based on the supply voltage to the probe.
For example in my 24V system i used a 20kohm and a 5Kohm resistor to create a voltage divider to create approximately 4.8v.

I suggest watching Tom's Guide on auto bed leveling, available on Youtube:
(Tom Sanladerer) search for 3D printing guides: Setting up auto bed tramming leveling tilt compensation!

The "emmrev3_ridged_side_flat_for_zprobe.STL" file is directly from the MakerGear Github Repository at [https://github.com/MakerGear/M2/tree/master/Experimental Parts/Z Probe for auto-level], I have included it here for convenience. All credit for the part goes to the MakerGear Team.

title: REPRAP Discount Graphic LCD case holder for Rostock Mini

description.text:
LCD Case holder Remix for Rostock mini 3d printer. LCD Case was taken from PabloGil Project: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213852. he sugested a edge mounting for his LCD, but, as i've installed all electronics underneath the machine, extending the wiring harness of LCD would be too complicated. i decided to attach the LCD on the lower part of the sliding rods, which due to mechanics of the machine, carriages can't reach the mount.

Hardware Required:
4 x 3x10mm selft tapping or machine bolts
4x 3x20mm hex bolts
4 x 3mm security nuts
4 x 3mm washers

Printer:

Rostock Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Rotate the model to print it from its side. no supports are required.

Measure the position of the LCD casing from the holder as you wish. LCD case has no modifications as the holder can be installed lower or higher if you needed. measure holes position and drill the back case of the LCD. attach the holder with the bolts. a litle of acetone can be used to weld the holder to the case. install the LCD following the instruction of Pablo Gil project.

To install the LCD, you must dissasemble the top of the machine, remove the idler holder from the desire axis (i've installed in the X axis), remove the carriage carefully and slide the lcd. mine is installed at 85mm from the lower plate of the machine. make sure the carriage can't touch the holder. move the machine to the oposite direction of the LCD so the carriage moves to its lower position.

tighten the screws and connect the LCD wiring. you're done. reinstall the idler holder, the top plate. re-lubricate the rods. Probably a recalibration of the axis is required. Enjoy.

author: Keagan_Exsteen

title: Christmas Tree Lights - Modular and Rainbow style

description.text:
What every Christmas tree needs are LIGHTS! Inspired by pauloricca's LED Christmas tree from back in 2009, (thing 1406), it was hollowed out, a mounting hole added and a base designed to enable me to string a number of these together after fitting a colour changing LED to each one.  
The LEDs are widely available - and if four of them are wired in series, the set can be powered by a standard 12V DC plug-in mains adapter. As a set of 4 LEDs will only take around a total of 120mA, a mains adapter rated at 0.5A or more will easily cope with having four sets of them in parallel which is what I have done. (Photos show just three sets in parallel).

Each set of four lights requires four hollow Christmas trees, four stands and four LEDs. You can use whatever flavour of LED you like but my choice were the slow flashing rainbow type. You will also need connecting wire, heat shrink tubing to cover the soldered joints and connector pieces to join one string of LEDs to the next set. (As well as to the 12V DC power source). Wire the LEDs in series, bending the LED leads and pushing the wires into the groove underneath the stand. My wires were roughly 100mm long. Each set will also need two more wires through the grooves - one for the negative supply and a second for the positive. If you use wire colours other than the standard black and red, make sure that you note down which is which as you will destroy the LEDs if you wire them the wrong way round. (I took the opportunity to use wire out of my scrap box). The first set of lights needs to connect to your power supply - use a DC plug which matches the DC socket on the mains adapter. The end of this first string needs a socket so that it can supply power to the next set. I used standard 0.1" crimp terminals. From then on, apart from the last string, you need power in and power out connectors. The final string only needs power in. Check all your wiring before connecting any power and once you are happy, I suggest you test them one at a time. Thanks to NumberSix who provided the idea and then helped me to learn some of the skills needed to produce this thing in Sketchup. He also suggested that I print the Christmas trees using the spiralise feature in my slicing program. This feature prints a single shell by continuous movement of the Z axis which is ideal for hollow objects. The Christmas trees have a "normal', (not spiral), 0.5mm base and once that has printed, the spiral begins. If your slicer does not have such a feature just go for a single shell. The trees push fit onto the bases. My bases were printed in different colours - red, green, gold and black. Edit
I have now included an alternative STL for the hollow Christmas tree with a 10mm hole in its base should you have problems slicing the first version which I uploaded .

Description:
Designed to be printed at 0.2mm layer height.

This is a custom DarkDragonWing Dual Over Head Cam V8 Engine with a butterfly style intake supercharger. It is a 1/8 scale. Some of the parts are working and moving like a real engine.

Watch how to build this engine: Building DKDGWi 1/8 DOHC V8

Watch it in action: RC Modify 24 | Yeti DKDGWi V8 Supercharged Mad Max Style

Recommend printing "DKDGWi_RC_DOHCV8E_Crank_Coupler.stl" with ABS.

Required Item(s):
1x eBay Amazon MG995/MG996R Servo
1x eBay Amazon 4.3g Mini Servo
1x eBay Amazon 35mm x 3mm Stainless Steel Axle
23x eBay Amazon 683ZZ Ball Bearing 3x7x3mm
122x eBay M1.2x4mm Screw Self Tapping
13x eBay M1.2x3mm Screw Black

description.text: The top measures approximately 6" X 9" and will just fit flat onto a stock FlashForge Creator Pro (MakerBot) platform. There are three interchangeable front panels that will fit onto the front of the shelf, each with a unique design. You can print the one that you like. I put holes in the shelf to mitigate warping but it's good to ensure the design is sticking well before you let it go on too long. There are two small holes in the back to facilitate hanging the shelf with small nails. I got the best print when I didn't use a raft and printed the first layer at 40% speed, 180% width and 90% height.

title: Doctor Strange - Eye of Agamotto (remix)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a remix from thing #1929165. I added a holder [for battery and switch and/or MCU] and a holder for a RGB led. I used a 500mAH LiPo 3.7V battery, mini slide SPST switch and 10mm RGB led.
The only caveat to the original one is that you can't open and close the eye since the battery holder is covering it. I just opened the eye so that the led light will be shown.

The STL file description:
switchcover.stl is the holder for battery, mini switch and electronics
ledhole.stl is the holder of the 10mm RGB led. (1st lighting option)
NeoHolderv2.stl is the holder for the RGB NeoPixel. (2nd lighting option)

Hole Drill:
You will have to drill a hole in the original part (shown above) for the LED wires or NeoPixel wires.

Second Option electronics:
This can also hold an Adafruit trinket or Adafruit Flora and single RGB NeoPixel [Adafruit part#1260].

Future Remix (not shown):
I did a third option (with modification not shown) by adding NewoPixel Jewel 7 [Adafruit Part#2226] with gemma. I will need to add a recharge board for this future option.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The parts from the original requires supports. But the remixed added parts (RGB LED holder, RGB NeoPixel holder and holder [for switch and battery] do not require any supports. For the original parts I used FFCP(2016) and for the remixed added parts I used a UM2.

Post: UM2 Print bed

From top counter-clockwise:

  1. RGB NeoPixel Holder (2nd lighting option)
  2. RGB LED Holder (1st lighting option)
  3. Battery/Switch and/or MCU holder
    if you are using RGB LED only battery and switch is needed. MCU is needed if you use the RGB NeoPixel option.

title: TS5828 mount for S500 with heat sink and 30 mm cooling fan.

description.text:
The fact that VTX nowadays are getting smaller, it means there is less surface area to let the heat go and often cause overheat issues. This is especially the case with high power units like the Eachine TS5828 600mW. Why is overheat bad?
Your VTX can burn out during FPV flights and cause crashes
Running at this high temperature while in contact with other electronics in your aircraft could damage them.
It affects your range and transmitter efficiency as they depend on the working temperature
With this mod the temperature of TS5828 always remains very low allowing it to work properly. You will need: 1 x 30 mm fan 12V, 1 X aluminium heat sink, 6 small zip ties to fix the fan to the heat sink and the VTX to the mount. Install it with the the two lower screws that attach the front arm to the central board. Total weight 30 gr.

I would suggest this as the 3d printers they use are much higher quality. And the material is very robust. Ive been running the buttons on my Ducati for a few months now. No issues at all
comments.author: Caferacer76

description.text: Half length Duplo compatible straight train track rails with internal printing support structure for easy printing without additional supporting materials. The SCAD-file allows you to make the vertical rail part somewhat thicker and stronger (extrawidth parameter) to more easily support a child standing on it. comments.text:
Hi Guys,
I like the design. Which kind of bulb is compatible with a PLA print ? I am wondering if it can sustain the heat of the light....
Thanks
Dan
comments.author: danbendavid

comments.text: Thanks for the comment! When it comes to lighting, incandescent and halogen light bulbs can emit heat over 200 degrees C. PLA has a glass transition temperature approximately between 60 - 65 degrees C. This means PLA would start softening and even morph shape. Compact fluorescent bulbs can emit heat up to 150 degrees C however the air around the lights doesn't usually get that hot. Therefore I would suggest using energy efficient compact fluorescent bulbs or LED lights as they not only emit less heat, but also save more energy. Personally I haven't experienced any problems with my CFL bulbs. Hope this helps.
comments.author: danbendavid

comments.text: Love the design, however when I import this into Repetier Host it is super tiny :D At first I thought it might be because of imperial/metric but scaling by 25.4 only brings it to about 40mm in diameter. Gone to 100 which looks about right, but not sure :)

For indoor or outdoor plants to keep them hydrated. Intended to be used as a supplement to regular watering. But can also be used used as a primary source when watering is not possible, as during a vacation.

After many design modifications, I opted for this one. Which during my tests, should last just under a week -- depending on how your machine prints the tip of the lower section. The .stl includes a tiny hole on the tip, but my machine didn't print it. Which might explain why the "irrigation" lasted almost a week. However, this can be easily fixed by slightly cutting off the tip with an X-ACTO. In my opinion, it's better that it lasts longer, than shorter. But not too long of course! All other side holes printed fine btw.

PLEASE USE ABS! I don't think PLA (or other filaments) will work properly. My experience has shown ABS works fine with water...does not leak or disintegrate over time..

Print the two parts standing upright, then assemble together. NOTE that it's a tight fit -by design, to prevent leakage. Fits most plastic 16.9 oz (500 mL) water bottles. Even larger ones such as 33.8 oz (1L). As the pictures show.

.2 micron
35% infill
2 perimeter shells
3 top and bottom layers

title: Kusmi tin wall rack for scarfs

description.text:
Got a bunch of empty Kusmi Tea tins? Put them on the wall and use them for storing and organizing your scarfs!

Make the rings match the colors of the tins or make them stand out - the choice is yours!

Printer:

Sculpto

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

Print on any setting.
Printed in PLA.

Extra items needed

Kusmi tins! Go for the 250g ones if you want it to be able to hold a scarf.
Make sure the tins are 'new' as the 'old' tins with the labels have a 'ridge' near the top and will not fit through the rings!

Get som Ø 6mm nuts and bolts. The ones I've used are 20mm long, however 10mm is enough (but they didn't have any shorter and I didn't care to go to another store).
I also got some washer (spændeskiver) so I didn't have to print spacers to go between layer one and three (where only two rings intersect). I also used them where layer two and three intersected without layer one, to ensure the bolts had the same distance from the wall (flush).

6mm nuts and bolts (and optional washers) Assembly

When you've printed the rings, get your nuts and bolts out. If you have not bought washers (spændeskiver) you may want to print some 1.5mm spacers.
Below I will refer to the 'smooth side' this is the one where the ring is flat (as opposed to the side, where there is an indentation to fit another loop). The smooth side will be the one touching the print plate.

Step 1: Lay out the rings loosely to form the shape you want.

Step 2: Split the rings into three layers; no ring mush touch a ring from the same layer.
Layer one (natural and green in my pictures): Smooth side up.
Layer two (pink in my pictures): Smooth side down.
Layer three (brown in my pictures): Smooth side up.

Step 3: Put bolts through the loops in layer one (except the loops where it will not be intersecting with other rings).

Step 4: Add layer two on top of layer one.

Step 5: If there are loops that do not intersect with layer one, but will intersect with layer three: Put a 1,5mm spacer or a washer on a bolt and put it through those loops.

Step 6: If there are are bolts not covered by layer two add a 1,5mm spacer or a washer to those bolts.

Step 7: Add layer three on top of layer two.

Step 8: Screw nuts onto all the bolts.

Yay! you have now assembled the 'net'!

Assembly of the three 'layers'. Layer assembly Hanging the assembled 'net'

Step 1: Work out how many points you want it hanging from (mine is hanging from a loop in each of the top brown rings).

Step 2: As you want the net to hang flat against the wall print a spacer for each hanging-loop. The head of my bolts are 3mm thick and 1,5mm must be added for every layer:
Hanging loop in layer one: 3mm spacer
Hanging loop in layer two: 4,5mm spacer
Hanging loop in layer three: 6mm spacer
Alternatively stack washers to get the needed height.

Step 3: Ready the wall for hanging by hold the net to the wall and mark through the loops you will be hanging it from.

Step 4: Drill holes (if necessary).

NOTE: If you are fixing the net to the wall (so you can't take if down without tools) remember step 5 (below)
If you are making the net removable (the head of whatever holding it is less than 7mm so the net can be lifted off) you may delay step 5 and simply take the net down afterwards to add the tins.

Step 5: ADD THE TINS! Slide the empty Kusmi Tins through the rings so the bottom of the ting touches the ring (or is level with the bolts).

Step 6: Using the spacers (from step 2) attach the net to the wall. You may want to add a washer on top of the hanging loop.

Step 7: Put scarfes in the tins

Use a spacer behind the handing loop to make the net hang properly Add scarfs for decoration Expanding the 'net'

If you want to expand the net later, either take the net down or make the addition 'on wall'.
Simply unscrew any connecting nuts/bolts and add bolts, nuts and spacers where needed.

I've added some extra rings from the start. As my net is only attached at the top I am able to make enough distance between the wall and the back of the rings that I can slide extra tins into the rings.

Thoughts and design

To get my Kusmi tins on the wall I had a number of different ideas, after a few failed attempts I thought of using my 3D printer.
Each tin slides into a ring and the rings then have to be connected. This makes it modular and expandable. To connect the rings I made loops where a bolt can fit through and be fastened with a nut.

I've found that a print is fairly sturdy when 3mm thick, so this was the thickness I went for for the rings, to make sure they stay ring-shaped and do not break. I also know that even a 1mm print, though flexible is also durable.
To not make the construction too bulky I opted to make the connector loops half the thickness of the rings (1,5mm).
The holes in the loops are 7mm.

I did try to come up with a printable solution for the nut and bolt, but it seemed too much of a hassle to print af actual nuts and bolts a easy to buy.

Items also available on tinkercad:
Ring: https://tinkercad.com/things/4AMexAaWYaD
1,5mm spacer: https://tinkercad.com/things/8rH6Nd3nltH

author: smat06

title: Allen Edmonds briefcase clip inlay and damage filler ML

description.text:
The Allen Edmonds brand offers a briefcase where the metal clip part is advertised as "Solid brass hardware with gun metal finish". Obviously, the hardware is solid but in no way holds up. Worn down clips are a real risk to the owner, and clip change is not made easy as these are bolted (but not screwed) in place. This all points to cheap manufacturing. To anticipate the problem of a broken clip, lost bag, damaged clip or having to prematurely deal with lost items, one has to avoid total damage to the part. If one buys a new bag, one may want to enforce the clip right from the start (then use a modified version of this inlay whose rectangular protrusion is made to reside inside the defect).

Luckily we can create inlays to alleviate the problem. These can be obtained on Shapeways in different materials.
https://www.shapeways.com/product/PLF5GBWP6/taschendings

This shape was approximated over 3 iterations (i.e. design, print, test, redesign, print, test, revise, print, test, bazinga).

title: Small collection of wooden train track compatible pieces.

description.text:
Inspired by other wooden train track designs I decided to make my own.

I wanted a chamfer on all the pieces so that after printing I am not left with very sharp edges. After importing others designs in FreeCAD, I was not able to chamfer the .stl files successfully.

So, I made my own designs. With the help from http://www.woodenrailway.info/track/trackguide.html I got the exact dimensions for all the tracks.

Most tracks come with grooves on top and bottom so that for example curves are automatically a left and right curve.

Besides the standard track pieces there are also a few special pieces, like the outer curve track of a double track (Brio EE) piece.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

24%

Notes:

Print the supports in a grid pattern with 25% fill. Distance x/y 1mm, distance z 0.15mm. 0.8mm shell, 0.75mm top/bottom.

I used PLA plastic and printed it really fast (top/bottom 50mm/s, outer shell 60mm/s, inner shell 70mm/s, infill 80mm/s) on high temperature (230 celsius). Works out great.

Step 1: Remove supports.

Yep. Remove the supports.

Step 2: Flame polish ugly white spots.

I used a small gas torch to flame polish the plastic where the supports were .

After removing the supports you get left with ugly white spots. A quick pass with the torch polishes the plastic. But do not over do it, or you are left with a warped or molten piece.

FreeCAD 3-way switch FreeCAD parameter definition using spreadsheet. Building in FreeCAD

I used FreeCAD to build the track pieces. First I defined all the design parameters in the spreadsheet. When sketching, I referred to the dimensions in the spreadsheet.
That way I could very quickly generate new track variants.
I only designed 1 curved track. Then used the spreadsheet to generate all curve variants. No more designing over and over.

I used FreeCAD to validate dimensional fitness. Using a H1 cross and 4 3-way pieces, you can make a large 4 way switch.

title: Dial Indicator Mount for Mendelmax 3 / V-Slot Carriages

description.text:
I have been using my digital calipers to level the bed on my Mendelmax 3, but it's a clunky process and prone to errors.

I designed a mount for a dial indicator that allows me to level more consistently. It is attached to either side of the v-slot rail and works very well.

Make sure you print with a decent infill. The mount attaches to the v-slot via friction, so you don't want any "squish" in the part. The is also a through-hole to attach the dial indicator to the mount, but I've found that the fit is close enough that this is not necessary.

This could also work with any printer that utilizes the same v-slot for X-axis traversing. Enjoy!

description.text:
I traced this from a pic in Solidworks 2016.

I am printing the backing in black and the carp in color as decoration for the drawer handles on my fish tackle box.

The back is only 0.6mm and the carp 1.2mm

Laser Gun - ESP driver

This is the driver of ESP8266 for the Timed Laser Gun project (here the WebInterface), a remix of
Remotely controlled torch robot by JJRobots.
Timed Laser Gun project is an automatic toy to let you cat play with laser pointer. I used an ESP to control the servo motors and a RTC to
provide a correct timing to schedule the events.

Running on ESP NodeMCU

To programm the ESP, use the Arduino IDE, then follow this step :

  • Go on File > Preferences, and change the URL of Board Manager with "http://arduino.esp8266.com/package_esp8266com_index.json", then click OK
  • Now go on Tools > Board:Arduino one > Board Managers
  • Search For "esp8266" and Click Install ( it will take a while )
  • After installation go back on Tools > Board:Arduino one and click on "NodeMCU 0.9 (ESP-12E Module)"
  • Now you can connect it and lunch the Load process

Build Hardware

The hardware part is made by :

  • x1 ESP8266 NodeMCU
  • x2 Servo motor 9g
  • x1 RTC

I used an RTC, to have a real timinig and schedule the event, but you can also use a Virtual RTC to simulate the timer
( obviously it will not be precise like RTC but you can every day sync with a remote server and it will be enough ).

Here the class I wrote and here how to use it :

void setup(){
  //String TimeNow = YourCustomTimeService.getStringTime(); // this in case you have a service that provide this string date format dd/mm/yyyy HH:mm:ss
  String TimeNow = "dd/mm/yyyy HH:mm:ss";
  String d =  TimeNow.substring(0,2);
  String h =  TimeNow.substring(3,5);
  String m =  TimeNow.substring(6,8);
  String s =  TimeNow.substring(9,11);
  rtc_timer = Rtc();
  rtc_timer.setup(d.toInt(), h.toInt(),m.toInt(),s.toInt());
}
void loop() {
  rtc_timer.loopTime();
  int seconds = rtc_timer.getSeconds();
  int minutes = rtc_timer.getMinutes();
  int hours = rtc_timer.getHours();
  int days = rtc_timer.getDays();
  // here you will use it
}

I removed the soldered pins just to save space, but I think you can do it without desoldering, just force a little bit.
Use this ( I not if is ugly I'm not a painter :D ) datasheet to build the hardware, I just make a simple list of connection points:

Servo X
  • GND -> GND
  • Vcc -> Vcc ( +5 )
  • Sign -> D6
Servo Y
  • GND -> GND
  • Vcc -> Vcc ( +5 )
  • Sign -> D5
RTC
  • GND -> GND
  • Vcc -> Vcc ( +3 )
  • SDA -> D2
  • SCL -> D1
Battery

(do not plug microUSB and connect battery simultaneously, I didn't try but I suggest to do not try)

  • Positive -> Vcc ( +5 )
  • Negative -> GND
Here the datasheet

Here my result

Then put all in the base case, use 2/3 mm screws ( I'm not sure ) to fix the ESP to the base, and that's it, program it and enjoy it.

USE the Laser Gun

author: ivan1994

title: Tevo Tarantula X-Carriage with Fan and Belt Tensioner

description.text:
A replacement carriage for the Tevo Tarantula stock X-Carriage, with built in X belt tensioner, dual fan mounts for 5015 blower fans, and auto level sensor mounts.

I designed this x-carriage to replace the stock acrylic one after it became soft and warped during a high temperature print in an enclosure. It is the same dimensions as the stock carriage, but has an inbuilt belt tensioner, supports both the stock hot end and the e3d v6, has mountings for dual fan ducts, and auto level sensor. I've included a fan duct for a 5015 blower on one side, printing it mirrored will give a second fan duct for the other side, and a sensor/fan mount for the SN04 or an M8 proximity sensor for auto levelling. If you wanted to use a second fan duct you'd need to modify one of the sensor brackets to add a second support for the duct.

I've just finished printing this in ABS, and will upload some pictures of it fitted to my printer once I get a chance to actually mount it.

description.text:
This is a Robotic gripper that adjusts its grip to conform to the shape and form of the object picked up.
UPDATE 2013/12/7 :-
I was pretty gobsmaked by the interest this gripper has attracted
and thanks to all for the kind messages.
The Gripper has now been Featured on :-
http://hackaday.com/2013/12/03/compliant-robot-gripper-wont-scramble-your-eggs/ Its printed with normal PLA (ie does not have to be flexi pla)
Video in action :- http://youtu.be/4MQmlvzE0i8
More details of build can be found on my robot page here :-https://hackaday.io/project/1011-trimaxgripper-linear-servo-actuator-gm
The drive mechanism is a simple standard servo modified with a linear actuator made from a "Glue stick" and linear feedback potentiometer.
Details on servo conversion can be found here:- http://youtu.be/sI8tvjdhYxw

Simple print parts with normal PLA , the STL files are orientated for printing without support, you may need to slow the printer down whilst the last part of the support beams are being printed.
Glue the three (red) support beams to the front (blue) body.
Add wire (paper clip wire) between the eyelets of the three arms.
I highly recommend you watch the above videos for details of actuator build.
More build details can be seen here :- https://hackaday.io/project/1011-trimaxgripper-linear-servo-actuator-gm
Fit in the linear Servo mechanism (i used a Pritt-stick as body and a lip gloss tube as the plunger (glue the plunger insert spigot inside the lip gloss tube) and glue the plunger crown (green) to the top of the lipgloss tube). It is done this way so that you can fine tune (sliding the crown up/down) to bring the gripper ends together to give max. grip
The Servo is a standard HS-311 - when converted to a linear actuator it can push 3kg of force.

description.text:
This is a modular bauble ornament allowing you to make a variety of different ornaments from the same collection of pieces.
By varying the colors and choosing which add-ons to stick onto the ball you can create many different baubles that can hang on a tree.

This print was made on a MakerBot Replicator 2.
I scaled every piece by 120% but you can go higher.
Try to print the add-ons and pegs at the highest resolution.
The ball, top and bottom work well at 0.15 mm.
There is a snap-fit peg used for connecting the top and bottom to the ball.
The snowflakes have their "snug-fit" pegs built in but the other add-ins have separate pegs to push in. You may have to do a bit of sanding on the pegs if they are too tight.

print_settings.Notes:: I used a 0.8mm nozzle to print this as I wanted it quickly and not all that bothered by a smooth finish on it. However no reason why it can't be printed at great resolutions just with a longer print time.

description.text:
At home I have a Tefal Quick Cup for my hot drink making needs. An annoying issue with it is that it will sometimes drip after you have removed the mug from under it. This means a small puddle forming under the machine. I did have a simple glass stand for the mug to sit on, but obviously the water could flow off. It also didn't really match the machine well. So I designed this drip tray. It consists of two parts, the drip tray and a grill to go over the top.

I printed the tray in black and the grill in bronze PLA. I know, PLA isn't known for dealing with hot liquids well, but it is only a small amount and should cool quickly enough to not be a problem! If worried, go with ABS or some other higher temperature plastic :D

Printer:

Custom

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.6

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used a 0.8mm nozzle to print this as I wanted it quickly and not all that bothered by a smooth finish on it. However no reason why it can't be printed at great resolutions just with a longer print time.
Should just need pushing together. There is a 0.25mm tolerance around the grill to make it a simple push fit.

Clip for holding a 3mm print bed in place and for easy removal.
One in each corner is recommended.

Ever wondered why they only put 1 or 2 holes in the edge of the reel, and always in the wrong place???
Well this helps to solve the problem of trying to drill more holes in a reel.
Print out a clip, Heat it and place it on the edge (Not all reels have the same thickness edge). Slips on and off fairly easily so you can just pop your filament through the hole, clip it on the edge of the reel and you shouldn't come back to an unwound reel lying all over the floor.

author: Vall3design

description.text:
I've Retired this and doing a Linux based controller instead. Check out http://goo.gl/tb8cU instead. After seeing the MightyBoard from MB, I said to my self, where's the state of the art. Where's all the nice new things, So I made this board instead. Features are as follows :- 32-Bit CPU running at 66mips.
SPI based Stepper controllers.
USB Host support.
Android Interface hook up.
Bluetooth support via USB dongle.
Plugable Mosfet Board.
Mosfets back to 12v. (24v is fine for driving stepper type things but makes it more difficult to find Fans, and other common devices that run at 24v). Dual Thermocouple support. Onboard RGB LED support. Selectable 12v,24v,36v Stepper drivers. Expandable, and if you so choose not to have the SPI based steppers (IE you want to reuse your exsiting steppers), then the board has enough breakout pins to put in a step-direction breakout board. Thus you could use the power of the 32-bit processor to control your Cupcake/Thingomatic using it's stepper controllers (PCB to follow). Basically it has everything you want from the Mighty board but with added extra umpfh (mmmh is that even how umpfh is spelt). I plan to submit this to the PCB makers in the next few days, If you spot anything untoward or an omission then shout. Update: PCB ordered. Now just have to wait for the postman. Update 16/4: PCB has arrived now need to put it all together. Slight issue with one off the connectors hole size. Update 22/5: It's ALIVE!. muwhahaha!. I've managed to get it talking to my Android Phone. Now to populate the rest of the board and put on some control software. Stay Tuned! Update 15/09: Going the way of the Pi. That's Raspberry PI. So I'm going to change the Main board from being a AtmelU3C Processor to a Raspberry Pi instead. I was working out the sums. For me to add USB, Ethernet, the processor and all the other bits, It would be cheaper to swap all that out for a Pi instead. So Going to start experimenting with this option. What it will give is a much more powerful system for less. Including on board GCODE manipulation. Full Gui interface, Full Ethernet capability and everything good that Linux has to offer.
Watch this space for a derivative.

No real instructions as yet. More things to do.
  • Get Board made up.
  • Solder board together.
  • Port Firmware from 8-bit processor to 32-bit processor.
  • Add Android SDK support.
  • Create Android control app.
  • Put it all together and watch the awesomeness.
  • Actually do all the above and not get distracted by newer even better designs.
    • Stepper board details http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19387
    CPU used http://www.atmel.com/Images/doc32117.pdf The board picture has some arrows detailing faults and clues as to what things are. I'm using the AVRDragon from atmel because it's cheap. I'm using the aWire interface which can be located on the AVRDragon on the JTAG header. PIN 3 (aW or TDO),4 (+3.3v or vtg) and 10 (gnd). These three must be connected and the board powered up for aWire to work and be able to program this chip.

title: Syma X5 Camera Locking Camera Mount!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Be sure to check out our web site and YouTube channel at http://Video-Drone.DIY3DTech.com for more information on this and other builds! As here what we did is designed a 3D printable camera mount for the Syma X5 series drone/quadcopter to allow other cameras, or accessories to be added. There are three versions, the first is a "blank" version you can use in your remixes (please post your results), the second has a mounting loop while the third is designed to to mount to that "mounting loop".

Want to find out more about this design and the 3D Printing of this part? Well check our video at https://youtu.be/3xlpj1SMOhA for more information and while your there don't forget to subscribe to the channel to be updated when we release something new!

What you don't have a Syma X5? Check out this link (http://amzn.to/2gCCmcX) as if your interested in getting involved drone this is both an easy and affordable to join the hobby! Oh, did I mention there is a ton of stuff to 3D print for these? A great combination of the two hobbies!

title: Pedal Extension for Electric Unicycle - new version
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A common issue with many Electric Unicycyles seems to be that the pedals are too short for many riders, so I made some pedal covers, which will extend them on both ends and on the outer edge. Also they will cover the sharp edges on the metal pedals. The pedals will still fold up normally even with these covers attached.

This is a revised version which is more rounded than the previous one, which had some issues with the outer corners sometimes touching the ground in tight turns.

These will fit pedals that are 17 cm long and have straight ridges (like the ones sold by Shenzen Microworks). Check pictures for details on compatible pedal version! The pedal cover´s grooves will lock to the ridges and prevent them from sliding off, but if you want to continue using them, I suggest that you attach them with two short M5 screws on each pedal. You´ll need to drill a small hole into the top of your metal pedal and cut a M5 thread (or use an M5 nut inside the pedal). Also, I recommend to add some anti-slipping tape to the top surface of the pedal cover.

Despite being made of PLA or ABS plastic, stability should not be an issue since all the main weight is still carried by the metal pedal underneath, so there is no significant load on the extended parts. It seems quite unlikely that these pedal covers could break unexpectedly in other situations than a crash or ground contact.

comments.text: Great job, they are practical and beautiful. Sadly, they are too big for my printer (200x200x170). Can you print a pair for me?
comments.author: Godehart

comments.text: Thanks for your feedback. Each pedal cover takes about 8-10hrs to print, so it´s a 2 day job for a pair. Unfortunately I currently have a couple of extensive printing projects going on, so my printing capacity is pretty much booked, but maybe you know someone nearby who owns a larger printer?
comments.author: Godehart

description.text: conversation from an known hobby jigsaw to a "hotwire"-version to cut styrofoam in the easy way.

• printed in PLA, 20% infill, 0.1mm layerheight.
  • you need also two stripped wire clips (in german called "Luesterklemme") with its screws for 1,5mm2 wire diameter.
  • for the electrical i use this resistor wire : 0,3mm 19 Ohm/m Kanthal
  • for the best resulting temperatur to cut styrofoam i took a adjustable power supply : 3.1V, 1.25A
    • feel free to experiment with other resistor wire and values

title: Rob Jackson's personalized business card holder

description.text:
This was my first dive into the Thingiverse environment. As part of an online introductory 3D printing course, we had an assignment to remix/customize a thing on the website. In an earlier assignment, we were asked to tell what thing we'd liked to 3D print if we could. I said, business card holders because I thought that it would make a good conversation piece and would create a perfect icebreaker for launching into my additive manufacturing "elevator speech". This a very basic edit on the business card holders developed by:

Designed by the be3D Creative Team:
Tomáš Kubata - Designer
Martin Žampach - Creative Director

I'm sure I didn't do everything 100% correct, but I look forward to continuing to learn more about 3D modeling and printing. Thanks guys for an awesome model!
Follow this link to edit in 3D!! https://www.3dslash.net/slash.php?alias=f41ec760510da89730f317d44dc377113730901a4941dad65b0374e6b0a6ebe9

author: jrobjackson888

title: filament spool roller base whith no metal parts
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
P3steel style spool roller by toolson looks cool.
however the bearings i have are 608ZZ and i don't want to use metal parts if it is not necessary.
so i remixed it

  1. short width frame. 628ZZ:8mm ->608ZZ:7mm
  2. no metal screws, no nuts. i added 4.7mm shaft to the washer.

if you have 628 bearings and you just not want to use metal parts, print toolson's original frame and my remixed washer.

if the shaft doesn't fit well, heat the shaft and pinch it with pliers.
i feel happy if you post pictures.
